journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine

title-group.article-title: Determination of remodeling parameters for a strain-adaptive finite element model of the distal ulna

contrib-group.aff: The Jack McBain Biomechanical Testing Laboratory, Department of Mechanical & Materials Engineering, Western University, London, ON, Canada

author-notes.corresp: Cynthia E Dunning, The Jack McBain Biomechanical Testing Laboratory, Department of Mechanical & Materials Engineering, Western University, Spencer Engineering Building, Room 2077, London, ON N6A 5B9, Canada. Email: cdunning@uwo.ca

abstract.p: Strain energy–based adaptive material models are used to predict bone resorption resulting from stress shielding induced by prosthetic joint implants. Generally, such models are governed by two key parameters: a homeostatic strain-energy state (K) and a threshold deviation from this state required to initiate bone reformation (s). A refinement procedure has been performed to estimate these parameters in the femur and glenoid; this study investigates the specific influences of these parameters on resulting density distributions in the distal ulna. A finite element model of a human ulna was created using micro-computed tomography (µCT) data, initialized to a homogeneous density distribution, and subjected to approximate in vivo loading. Values for K and s were tested, and the resulting steady-state density distribution compared with values derived from µCT images. The sensitivity of these parameters to initial conditions was examined by altering the initial homogeneous density value. The refined model parameters selected were then applied to six additional human ulnae to determine their performance across individuals. Model accuracy using the refined parameters was found to be comparable with that found in previous studies of the glenoid and femur, and gross bone structures, such as the cortical shell and medullary canal, were reproduced. The model was found to be insensitive to initial conditions; however, a fair degree of variation was observed between the six specimens. This work represents an important contribution to the study of changes in load transfer in the distal ulna following the implementation of commercial orthopedic implants.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Distal ulnar arthroplasty (DUA) is a procedure used to restore joint strength and range of motion at the distal radioulnar joint (DRUJ) for patients suffering traumatic fracture or severe arthritis. It involves replacement of the distal ulnar head with a prosthetic implant that includes a stemmed component fixed into the medullary canal of the ulna. One drawback to DUA is that loads normally borne by bone tissue are instead diverted through the stiffer prosthetic, leading to a phenomenon known as stress shielding. In response, the body decreases the density of the shielded tissue via bone resorption. This “bone remodeling” is described by Wolff’s law,1 which characterizes bone as a dynamic material, changing its density and microstructure in response to changes in external loading conditions.

This loss of density is detrimental to long-term implant stability, increases risk of fracture, and reduces the amount of bone stock available for future revision surgeries.2 As a result, much research has emerged relating implant design and stress shielding; however, the bulk of this research has been for the hip joint. While the hip and DRUJ both involve long bones, the loading environment of each joint is unique, and thus, the ulna merits a separate investigation.

To the authors’ knowledge, only two studies address stress shielding and load transfer in the distal ulna. One examined the relationship between stem length and material properties on load transfer from implant to bone,3 and the other used a finite element (FE) analysis to compare the degree of stress reduction in cortical bone resulting from the implantation of two commercially available prosthetics.4 These studies were limited by the fact that only one time point was considered. Since remodeling due to stress shielding occurs over time, a more insightful evaluation of implant design should incorporate a temporal component.

Material models of bone tissue have been developed to mimic the remodeling capacity of bone.5–10 Cowin and Hegedus10 developed the theory of adaptive elasticity, which used deviations from an assumed homeostatic strain state to dictate bone remodeling. This theory has since been modified to incorporate elastic material properties, using strain energy or an “effective stress” measure as the reference state, which has produced favorable results in studies involving human and animal bone physiology.7,11–17

Verification that a model can recreate bone density distributions corresponding to applied loads is an essential first step before application to implant design and requires refinement of model parameters. This can be done by creating a three-dimensional (3D) discretized FE mesh of a physiological bone, initializing it with a homogeneous density distribution and applying assumed physiological loads that drive the remodeling procedure using assumed model parameters. Once the model has achieved steady state, calculated density values are compared with the physiological density distribution. This procedure for model parameter determination has been performed in the proximal femur and the glenoid,11,18–21 but not yet in the distal ulna, which is the purpose of the present work.

sec.title: Scanning and geometry
sec.p: Micro-computed tomography (µ-CT) images of the right ulna of a 76-year-old male (isotropic voxel spacing of 152 µm, eXplore Ultra; GE Healthcare, London, Canada) were imported into Mimics® (Materialise, Leuven, Belgium), where the ulna’s surface geometry was extracted and exported to Abaqus CAE® (Simulia, Providence, RI, USA). A FE mesh of 352,907 elements was created, with an average edge length and aspect ratio of 1.04 mm and 1.58, respectively. Second-order tetrahedral elements were used, as they have greater meshing flexibility compared with hexahedral elements while still accurately reproducing in vitro bone strain.22,23

A program developed in-house registered the FE mesh to the original µ-CT images and mapped the physiological density distribution. An SB3 cortical bone phantom (Gammex Inc., Middleton, WI, USA) with a known density of 1.82 g/cm3 included in each CT scan, along with the knowledge that the surrounding medium was air (∼0 g/cm3), established a relationship between Hounsfield Units (HUs) and density (g/cm3). The program then used this relationship to calculate an apparent density per element based on the Hounsfield values of the voxels contained therein, creating a mesh with the physiological density distribution of the ulna.

sec.title: Loading and boundary conditions
sec.p: The ulna was set to a fully fixed boundary condition approximately 150 mm proximal to the distal articular surface. In accordance with previous implementations of this model,11,21 strain-energy contributions from multiple bending loads applied from pronation to supination at the ulnar head’s articular surface were used to calculate strain energy, simulating loading from the radius; however, this resulted in increased density only within those loads’ corresponding bending planes. Thus, to reduce simulation time, a single bending load was applied medially in the frontal plane, and a 2-mm thick region of interest (ROI) symmetrical about this plane was constructed for quantitative analysis (Figure 1). The load magnitude was 20 N and based on in vitro measurements of forearm rotation.24

caption.p: Loading configuration applied to each ulna specimen. The region of interest used for analysis is the highlighted region in Section A–A

sec.title: Model parameters
sec.p: Following previous implementations in the femur and glenoid,12,18 the model used in the present work uses strain-energy density to characterize the homeostatic condition, expressed mathematically as

where ρ is apparent bone density (wet bone mass divided by volume (g/cm3)), t is time (arbitrary units), U is strain-energy density (J/cm3), K is the homeostatic strain-energy per unit mass (J/g), and s (unit-less scalar) represents a threshold difference in strain signal required for bone remodeling to occur. The scalar A (units of g2/cm3/J/time) is a proportionality constant that, for this study, is incorporated into the numerical time integration step.

Equation (1) is a first-order initial value problem and is solved numerically: apparent density values are assigned as state variables to mesh element integration points, a loading condition is applied, the FE method is used to calculate the strain field required to determine
d ρ
/ d ρ dt
dt
, and a corresponding change in density is computed by numerically integrating equation (1). The load is then released and changes in element density are implemented, thus completing one iteration of the remodeling process.

Iterations continued for a predetermined number of cycles. A convergence criterion was defined based on the largest change in density among all mesh elements, which was tracked for each iteration. If this value fell below 1e−5 g/cm3, then that iteration was flagged as a potential convergence point. After the simulation had run to completion, results were investigated to see whether the analysis had achieved the convergence criteria or whether flagged iterations corresponded to local minima or maxima. If the model had not yet converged, additional iterations were run, starting from where the previous simulation ended.

sec.title: Determination of parameters K and s
sec.p: The remodeling algorithm was implemented using equation (1). Values for K between 2500 and 4000 µJ/g, previously used in the femur,11,12 were initially implemented but produced overly stiff models with large cortical shells, indicating K was too large. Thus, K = 2500, 250, and 25 µJ/g were selected to determine an appropriate order of magnitude, from which further refinements could be made.

An approach that used the strain-energy field induced by the 20-N load when the ulna was set with its physiological density distribution as the homeostatic strain-energy state was also implemented. This involved an initialization step executed before the remodeling simulation, where the 20-N bending load was applied to the bone model set with its anatomic density distribution. The strain energy per unit mass was then calculated for each mesh element and used as that element’s value for K, resulting in a unique K value specific to each mesh element (referred to as element specific or ES). Values of s = 0.35, 0.55, and 0.75 were implemented, representing the spectrum of values reported from the literature,13,16,18 producing in 12 total K–s combinations.

Each model was initialized with a homogeneous density of 0.8 g/cm3.12 Upper and lower density limits were set to 0.01 and 1.85 g/cm3 to represent empty space and cortical bone, respectively.23 Isotropic and linear-elastic material properties were assigned per integration point using an empirical power law E = 8346ρ1.5 (E is elastic modulus in megapascal) and Poisson’s ratio of ν = 0.3, properties that have proven capable of predicting experimental strain values in the ulna.23

Time integration was executed using the Adams–Bashforth method.25 The time step for each iteration was such that the maximum change in density for any integration point in one iteration was 0.185 g/cm3 (10% of cortical density), with a maximum 100 time units per increment.

Each simulation was initially run for 100 iterations. The root mean square error (RMSE) between the calculated and physiological (i.e. derived from µ-CT) densities were calculated across all integration points within the ROI to get a sense of quantitative error, while average error was used to quantify over or underestimation. The K parameter of the model with the lowest RMSE was then further refined until subsequent adjustments resulted in no further reduction in RMSE.

As increased density only occurred within the plane of bending, elements outside this plane were excluded from RMSE calculations. Likewise, elements belonging to the part of the distal ulna removed during toxic unit approach (DUA) were also excluded from RMSE calculation because the intended application of the material model under investigation is to evaluate distal ulnar implant design, which influences resorption in the diaphysis, hence the focus on the diaphyseal region.

sec.title: Start density variation
sec.p: It has been noted that the use of an element-based (or similarly integration point-based) remodeling algorithm can be influenced by initial conditions.26 To determine the uniqueness of the model, simulations were run with initial densities of ρ0 = 0.4 and 1.2 g/cm3, with s and K set to their previously refined values.

sec.title: Different specimens
sec.p: The relative performance of the refined K and s parameters across a sample of ulnas was also tested. FE meshes were created from six additional right ulnas (5 M, 1 F, average age 66.5 years) using the procedures outlined in section “Model generation.” The number of elements in each mesh ranged from 384,190 to 488,115, with average edge lengths and aspect ratios between 0.92 and 0.98 mm and 1.55 and 3.55, respectively. An initial density of ρ0 = 0.8 g/cm3 and the refined values of K and s were used.

sec.title: Variation of K and s
sec.p: Figure 2 shows the development of the RMSE within the ROI for each of the 12 initial models. After 100 iterations, models using K = 2500 µJ/g (RMSE = 0.74–0.88 g/cm3) tended to underestimate density (average error = −0.61 to −0.49 g/cm3), producing an overly thin cortical shell and large medullary canal. Conversely, models using K = 25 µJ/g (RMSE = 0.59–0.61 g/cm3) failed to resorb the central volume, thus overestimating density (average error = +0.39–0.40 g/cm3). Models using an ES K value (RMSE = 0.76–0.82 g/cm3) also overestimated density (average error = +0.28–0.32 g/cm3), producing alternating bands of high and moderate densities throughout the ROI.

caption.p: Development of RMSE between calculated and scanned density values in the ROI for the initial ulna specimen.

Each data point represents output after 20 iterations of remodeling. Data points were sampled every 20 iterations of remodeling. All models were run for 100 iterations, with an additional 100 iterations run for models where K = 250 µJ/g. Note the scale of arbitrary time units on the x-axis, due to dynamic time integration, the number of elapsed time units per iteration varies depending on the value of dρ/dt.

sec.p: Models using K = 250 µJ/g had the lowest RMSE values after 100 iterations (RMSE = 0.46–0.49 g/cm3) and produced a cortical shell and medullary canal comparable with that of physiology. These models were run for a further 100 iterations to determine whether any further improvements and/or a steady RMSE value could be obtained.

After 200 total iterations, a steady RMSE was observed in models using K = 250 µJ/g, with s = 0.35 and 0.55 having the lowest RMSE value at 0.46 g/cm3. The average error for s = 0.55 and 0.35 was −0.10 and −0.15 g/cm3, respectively, and was used as the deciding factor to determine that s = 0.55 produced the most accurate results. Figure 3 displays the density distributions produced for models with s = 0.55.

caption.p: (a–d) Density distribution within the ROI of the initial ulna specimen (Specimen 1) after 200 iterations for models using s = 0.55 and (e) the distribution derived from the HU values of the CT scan.

sec.p: While maintaining s = 0.55, K was more finely tuned until no further improvement in RMSE was observed (Table 1). This occurred at K = 150 µJ/g, where RMSE = 0.41 g/cm3 and average error = +0.05 g/cm3 after 200 iterations. A mesh refinement test was also performed using these parameters with 736,683 elements at an average edge length of 0.804 mm and aspect ratio of 1.58. The RMSE after 200 iterations was 0.43 g/cm3, representing a change of less than 5% compared with the original mesh.

caption.p: Fine-tuning of the value for homeostatic strain state, K.

sec.title: Different start densities
sec.p: Models with initial density values ρ0 = 0.4/cm3 and 1.2 g/cm3 were created using the refined model parameters (i.e. K = 150 µJ/g and s = 0.55). Figure 4 plots the RMSE of these models over time, and Table 2 lists RMSE and average error at the conclusion of the analysis. Steady RMSE values were realized after 400 iterations (Figure 4).

caption.p: Development of RMSE between calculated and scanned density values in the ROI for the originally tuned ulna model (Specimen 1) using initial densities of ρ0 = 0.4, 0.8, and 1.2 g/cm3.

Remodeling parameter values were K = 150 µJ/g and s = 0.55. Data points were sampled every 20 iterations of remodeling. All models were run for 400 iterations. Note the scale of arbitrary time units on the x-axis, due to dynamic time integration, the number of elapsed time units per iteration varies depending on the value of dρ/dt.
Average and RMSE calculated after 400 iterations for the ROI for different starting densities ρ0 with K = 150 µJ/g and s = 0.55.

sec.title: Different specimens
sec.p: Table 3 lists the RMSE and average error of the ROI for each additional specimen in comparison with the original (Specimen 1) using K = 150 µJ/g, s = 0.55, and ρ0 = 0.8 g/cm3. Steady RMSE values were realized after 200 iterations (Figure 5).

caption.p: Average and RMSE calculated for the ROI on all specimens using ρ0 = 0.8, K = 150 µJ/g, and s = 0.55 after 200 iterations. The original tuned specimen is Specimen 1.
Development of RMSE between calculated and scanned density values in the ROI for all seven ulna specimens using ρ0 = 0.8 g/cm3, K = 150 µJ/g, and s = 0.55 (originally tuned specimen is Specimen 1).

Data points were sampled every 20 iterations, and all analyses were run for 200 iterations. Note the scale of arbitrary time units on the x-axis, due to dynamic time integration, the number of elapsed time units per iteration varies depending on the value of dρ/dt.

sec.title: Discussion of results
sec.p: Previous FE investigations of load transfer and stress shielding in the distal ulna have employed models of commercially available implants;4 however, these models did not consider a temporal component, and as the remodeling process is nonlinear,2 statically determined stress shielding patterns do not necessarily project the extent or progression of realized bone loss. Strain-based adaptive material models of bone offer a means to include temporal effects; however, variation in loading and biological factors (e.g. metabolism) between anatomical locations requires refinement of model parameters at a given location as a first step. In this study, a strain-adaptive material model of bone was, for the first time, applied to the human ulna in order to determine these parameters. Furthermore, the sensitivity of the model to initial conditions and interindividual variability was explored.

A homeostatic strain state of K = 150 µJ/g and dead-zone width of s = 0.55 achieved the smallest RMSE between predicted and physiological density values at 0.41 g/cm3, with density being slightly overestimated (average error of +0.05 g/cm3). These values compare well with those obtained by Sharma et al.,18 whose smallest reported RMSE values were ∼0.40 g/cm3 for a two-dimensional (2D) remodeling analysis of the glenoid. While RMSE serves well as an aggregate measure of error magnitude, it is noted that other remodeling studies have used different quantitative measures: Pérez et al. calculated average absolute error across different density domains;20 Turner et al. also used RMSE, but instead of an intact bone, compared the degree of postoperative bone loss using clinical and simulated dual energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) images.13 Given access to patient data, postoperative imaging could be used to validate the current model.

Weinans et al. identify the cortical shell and medullary canal as morphological features important to the qualitative assessment of a remodeling result12 and have been reported in previous remodeling simulations.2,13,17,19,26–28 As shown in Figure 3, our model was able to recreate the cortical shell and medullary canal of the ulna within the ROI, as well as a distal transition toward more cancellous bone, lending qualitative support to the present results.

Of note is the observation that the models using an ES K did not produce a medullary canal but rather had density plots similar to models using the smallest K of 25 µJ/g. The similarity of these models’ results might be due to the fact that, for the ES case, the reference strain-energy state (K) for elements within the medullary canal would be small compared with those near the cortical shell due to their proximity to the neutral bending axis. Furthermore, the remodeling process was started with an initially high ρ0, making the initial configuration relatively stiff and initial strains low. Considering that the remodeling process is driven by the difference between the induced and reference strain states, a small difference would mean a small rate of change, or none at all if the value of s is large enough. This last point is borne out in Figure 2, as RMSE for ES models increases with the increasing values of s. A direct comparison between an ES and constant homeostatic strain state has not been published before this study, and further investigations using a smaller initial density ρ0 or loading conditions in an ES model may be able to improve both qualitative and quantitative results.

The decision to initially set ρ0 = 0.8 g/cm3 was arbitrary, albeit informed from the literature.12 Setting ρ0 to 0.4 and 1.2 g/cm3 resulted in changes in final RMSE of 12.2% and 7.3%, respectively, corroborating the predictions of Fischer et al.26 that initial conditions play a role in final density distribution when using an element-based (or similarly, integration point-based) system versus a node-based one. An intermediate value of ρ0 = 0.8 g/cm3 resulted the lowest value for RMSE (Figure 4), with ρ0 = 0.4 g/cm3 underestimating and ρ0 = 1.2 g/cm3 overestimating final densities (Table 3). Based on these results, it is recommended that the average of minimum and maximum density values be used for the initial density condition in this type of analysis.

Some have advocated defining density values at element nodes instead of integration points, as the latter can lead to a “checkerboarding” effect, where adjacent mesh elements are either completely densified or resorbed, arguing that this does not represent physiology.11,25,27 These studies did not, however, employ a dead-zone width s, which in this case has mitigated checkerboarding. Sharma et al.18 also observed no checkerboarding when comparing the node- and integration point-based methods, recommending the use of the latter as it predicted physiological density values more accurately. This may be due to the large amount of averaging that occurs at mesh nodes, which occurs after each iteration.

A limitation of the present work is the use of an isotropic material model for bone, which is known to have orthotropic properties. The main reason for using isotropic material properties comes from the fact that modulus values are derived using HUs, which are themselves scalar data, and thus give no information regarding principal material directions. In addition, the material model used to effect changes in bone density uses strain energy as a stimulus, again a scalar value, and cannot by itself be used to model how principal material directions might change over time. Despite this, the isotropic assumption likely contributed very little to errors in calculated strain values, as it has been observed that results of isotropic versus anisotropic models show no significant difference in calculated strain values for long bones,29 especially when normal strains (e.g. those induced in bending) dominate.30

Variation in final RMSE across specimens ranged from 9.8% to 48.8% higher than the original specimen on which the parameter refinement was performed (Specimen 1), indicating that the parameters s and K are model dependent. One source of this variation can be explained by the fact that the same loading condition was applied to all specimens. The model validation is based on the assumption that a physiological loading condition will produce a physiological density distribution; thus, any error in assumed in vivo loading would propagate to the predicted density distribution.31 While the authors recognize that the prescribed 20-N bending load is a simplistic characterization, and not all individuals are subject to the same day-to-day loading, it was based on in vitro data acquired from an instrumented implant24 of a forearm in passive and active forearm rotation, which reported bending moments dominating over inferior-superior axis torsion.24,32 Axial loads were not included because, due to the moment-arm effect, normal stress caused by bending would dominate over those produced through axial loading.

In researching appropriate loading conditions to apply to the model, the authors noted a significant deficiency in the literature of data characterizing the loading across the DRUJ in vivo. This deficiency in load description highlights the need for more studies characterizing the internal loading environment within the DRUJ, a field to which this type of FE analysis can contribute to; that is, instead of reproducing a known density distribution from assumed loads, a known density distribution can be used to predict physiological loading.33

While the loading conditions used were one source of interindividual variability, results from studies employing an ES K value, which is one way to account for loading differences between individuals, still display high variability between individuals. For example, Sharma et al.18 reported RMSE between 0.40 and 0.75 g/cm3, or 87.5%, across the three models, which is on the order of that observed in the present study. This indicates factors other than loading are involved.

Another significant contributor to interindividual variability stems from the fact that the remodeling theory used does not account for nonmechanical factors (e.g. metabolism), which vary greatly between individuals while playing a role in the remodeling process.34 Despite this, many studies have demonstrated that the strain energy–based approach used in the present study can provide useful feedback on bone resorption caused by orthopedic implants, provided a similar refinement process is performed; however, these results are not always made explicit, and only references to qualitative results are used to justify the use of a given parameter value.12,18 The present study differentiates itself from those previous by explicitly and quantitatively investigating the impact of parameter variation in order to inform future investigators wishing to employ the presented material model.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Taken together, the data presented in this study represent the first application of a strain energy–based adaptive material model of bone to the ulna, achieving qualitative and quantitative results commensurate with models developed for other anatomical locations where commercial implant designs have been assessed using this technique.14,16 Moving forward, this model will be used to evaluate the impact of stress shielding caused by orthopedic implants on the density distribution in the distal ulna, allowing for better informed orthopedic design decisions.
